metadata.titleEn: Pollen spectra of Lake Xingxinghai covering the last 7400 years, Yellow River Source Area
metadata.description:
A 170-cm-long sediment core was extracted from Lake Xingxinghai at a water depth of 9 m (34°50.44′N, 98°06.34′E) in January 2010 using Austria’s UWITEC platform coring equipment. Both the 210Pb/137Cs and AMS 14C (11 dating data) approaches were applicated into the age-depth model establishment using Bayesian age–depth modelling by the “Bacon” software, and the age-depth model indicates the core covers the past 7400 years. The core was sliced at 0.5-cm interval upper 3 cm and 1-cm interval for other part, finally we got 173 samples totally. Pollen grains were extracted using a procedure including the treatments with 10 % HCl, 10 % NaOH and 40 % HF, followed by a 7-μm mesh sieving and acetolysis treatment (9:1 mixture of acetic anhydride and sulfuric acid). Pollen grains were identified and counted under optical microscope, and at least 300 terrestrial pollen grains were counted for each sample. The mean temporal resolution of pollen spectra is ca. 40 year/sample.
The pollen spectra include forty-eight pollen taxa, are dominated by herbaceous taxa (range: 88.5~98.9%; mean: 93.4%), such as Artemisia (up to 54.4%), Cyperaceae (up to 50.1%), Poaceae (up to 48.8%), Chenopodiaceae (up to 17.9%) and Asteraceae (up to 8.5%). Abundance of arboreal pollen is less than 5% through out the core, mainly comprised of Pinus (maximum: 4.9%; mean:1.2%) and Betula (maximum: 3.0%; mean: 0.7%). The pollen dataset includes pollen percentages for the 43 terrestrial pollen taxa together with their depths and ages, and the dataset is valuable to employed in past vegetation and climate reconstructions.
metadata.instructions: Pollen dataset is save in EXCEL file. the column is pollen names and row is sample with depth and age.

Palynological evidence for the temporal stability of the plant community in the Yellow River Source Area over the last 7,400 years. Veget Hist Archaeobot. https://doi.org/10.1007/s00334-022-00870-5

background: Understanding past vegetation variations and their driving mechanisms on a long-term scale provides a theoretical basis for current vegetation protection and restoration measures. Vegetation on the Tibetan Plateau (TP) is fragile and sensitive to climate changes and human impacts. With the TP warming 50% faster than the global average, the vegetation ecosystem is under threat and subject to change in the near future. Evolution of the vegetation on the Tibetan Plateau over a long period can reveal a pattern of global changes, such as changes in ocean circulation, the carbon cycle, climate and glacial cycles. Besides climate change, human activities such as grazing can severely impact local vegetation, cause grassland degradation and enhance soil erosion. Lacustrine pollen records with continuous sedimentation and high temporal resolution are an important archive of past vegetation changes on the TP and, along with other paleoenvironmental proxies, can be used to investigate the drivers of environmental change. Previous vegetational and environmental histories of the TP inferred from pollen data show strong spatial peculiarities. For example, pollen records from the south-eastern TP have revealed that the regional vegetation evolution is generally correlated with the evolution of the Indian Summer Monsoon, while the vegetation on the eastern TP is more strongly driven by the East Asian Summer Monsoon. Lake Xingxinghai (XXH) is located in the Yellow River Source Area (YRSA), which can be influenced by both the Asian Summer Monsoon (including Indian Summer Monsoon and East Asian Summer Monsoon) and the westerlies. Due to the importance of the YRSA for downstream ecosystems, ecosystem variations in this region have been investigated to understand the impact of climate change and human activities.
research objective: In this study, we analysed a lacustrine sediment core from XXH for pollen, grain-size, total organic carbon and carbonate content, with a reliable chronology based on 210Pb and 14C dating to investigate the past vegetation and environment covering the last 7,400 years. We aim to reconstruct the past vegetation and environment for the YRSA, investigate their driving factors, and determine whether past vegetation was disturbed by human activities in the YRSA.
challenges: The dating results from samples at 100, 115 and 140 cm deviated from the linear pattern, and we treat these dates as outliers and have excluded them from the age-depth model. These dates are older than expected, possibly reflecting erosion or an input of old carbon from the catchment area.
methods: A 170-cm-long sediment core was extracted from XXH at a water depth of 9 m in January 2010 using UWITEC’s piston corer equipment. For the upper 3 cm, the core was subsampled at 0.5 cm intervals; for the rest, it was sliced at 1 cm intervals, providing 173 samples in total. The top 12 cm of the core were analysed for 210Pb and 137Cs by direct gamma assay in the Liverpool University Environmental Radioactivity Laboratory using Ortec HPGe GWL series well-type coaxial low background intrinsic germanium detectors. A total of 11 samples from different depths including eight organic sediment samples, two plant material samples and one charred material sample were used for radiocarbon dating in the Poznan Radiocarbon Laboratory (Poland). Sediment samples were analysed for pollen composition, grain size, carbonate and total organic carbon. Approximately 1 cm3 of sediment was used for pollen extraction per sample. Coarse particles were removed by sieving through a 200-μm mesh, and one tablet of Lycopodium spores (approximately 27,637 ± 563 grains) was added to each sample for calculating pollen concentration. Pollen grains were extracted using a procedure including treatments with 10% HCl, 10% NaOH and 40% HF, followed by a 7-μm mesh sieving and acetolysis treatment. Pollen grains were identified and counted under an optical microscope, with the help of modern pollen reference slides for common plant species of alpine meadow in the eastern TP and pollen atlases. Grain-size analysis was performed using a MasterSizer 2000 laser grain-size analyser after samples were pretreated with 10% H2O2 to remove organic matter, 10% HCl to remove carbonate, and then sodium hexametaphosphate to disperse aggregates. Carbonate content was semi-quantitatively analysed by an X’Pert3 X-ray diffractometer. Total organic matter content (TOC) was extracted using the antititration method with concentrated sulfuric acid (H2SO4) and potassium dichromate (K2Cr2O7). It was then quantified using a CE440 Elemental Analyzer after being treated with 10% HCl at 80 °C to remove carbonate.
dataset: A 170-cm-long sediment core covering the last 7,400 years was collected from Lake Xingxinghai (XXH) in the YRSA. For the upper 3 cm, the core was subsampled at 0.5 cm intervals; for the rest, it was sliced at 1 cm intervals, providing 173 samples in total. The top 12 cm of the core were analysed for 210Pb and 137Cs by direct gamma assay. A total of 11 samples from different depths including eight organic sediment samples, two plant material samples and one charred material sample were used for radiocarbon dating.
findings: Dominant and common pollen components—Cyperaceae, Poaceae, Artemisia, Chenopodiaceae and Asteraceae—are stable throughout the last 7,400 years. Slight vegetation change is inferred from an increasing trend of Cyperaceae and decreasing trend of Poaceae, suggesting that alpine steppe was replaced by alpine meadow at ca. 3.5 ka cal bp. The vegetation transformation indicates a generally wetter climate during the middle and late Holocene, which is supported by increased amounts of TOC and Pediastrum (representing high water-level) and is consistent with previous past climate records from the north-eastern Tibetan Plateau. Our results find no evidence of human impact on the regional vegetation surrounding XXH, hence we conclude the vegetation change likely reflects the regional climate signal.

Verification.Question: Is the pollen extraction method used in the sediment core analysis consistent with conventional acid-base treatment techniques?
Can the age-depth model for the sediment core be considered reliable despite some dates being excluded as outliers?

Concept Completion.Question: What is a common method for extracting pollen from sediment samples in lacustrine environments?
Where was a dataset covering the last 7,400 years collected for studying past vegetation and environment changes?
What challenges might arise when constructing an age-depth model for sediment cores?

Example.Question: What is an example of a methodological challenge faced when constructing an age-depth model for paleoenvironmental research, and how was it addressed?
Example.Answer: A challenge encountered was that dating results from samples at 100, 115, and 140 cm deviated from the linear pattern, possibly due to erosion or input of old carbon. These dates were treated as outliers and excluded from the age-depth model to maintain its reliability.

Feature Specification.Question: What features or properties are typically considered when constructing an age-depth model for sediment cores?
Feature Specification.Answer: radiocarbon dating, gamma assay for 210Pb and 137Cs, Bayesian modeling software, outlier treatment

Quantification.Question: How many pollen samples were analyzed for vegetation and climate reconstruction over the past 7,400 years?
What is the time resolution of the pollen record extracted from the sediment core?
How many radiocarbon dating samples were used to establish the chronology of the sediment core?

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'lacustrine pollen records' in the context of studying past vegetation changes?
Definition.Answer: In the context of studying past vegetation changes, 'lacustrine pollen records' refer to pollen data obtained from lake sediments. These records provide continuous sedimentation and high temporal resolution, making them an important archive for investigating historical vegetation changes and environmental conditions over long periods, such as those on the Tibetan Plateau.

Definition.Question: How is 'Bayesian age-depth modeling' used in constructing age models for sediment cores?
Definition.Answer: Bayesian age-depth modeling is used to construct age models for sediment cores by incorporating chronological data, such as radiocarbon dates and other dating methods, to statistically model the relationship between depth and age. In the context of the sediment core from Lake Xingxinghai, Bayesian modeling with the Bacon software was used to establish a chronology for the core covering the last 7,400 years.

Definition.Question: What is the purpose of using 'Lycopodium spores' during pollen concentration calculations in sediment samples?
Definition.Answer: Lycopodium spores are used during pollen concentration calculations in sediment samples as a marker to accurately quantify pollen concentrations. By adding a known quantity of these spores to each sample, researchers can calculate the concentration of pollen grains based on the ratio of Lycopodium spores to pollen grains identified under the microscope.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about past climate conditions from the observed trends in pollen composition over the last 7,400 years?
Interpretation.Answer: The observed increase in Cyperaceae and decrease in Poaceae suggest a shift from alpine steppe to alpine meadow, indicating a generally wetter climate during the middle and late Holocene. This inference is supported by increased total organic carbon and Pediastrum, which represent higher water levels.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors could cause deviations in dating methods when constructing age-depth models in sediment core analyses?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The dating results from samples at 100, 115, and 140 cm deviated from the linear pattern, which were treated as outliers and excluded from the age-depth model. These dates were older than expected, possibly reflecting erosion or an input of old carbon from the catchment area.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might certain pollen types dominate in pollen records from lacustrine sediments over long periods?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Dominant and common pollen components such as Cyperaceae, Poaceae, Artemisia, Chenopodiaceae, and Asteraceae are stable throughout the last 7,400 years, which could be due to the regional vegetation stability and climatic conditions favoring these species.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the causes behind the transition from alpine steppe to alpine meadow inferred from pollen data in the Yellow River Source Area?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: A slight vegetation change is inferred from an increasing trend of Cyperaceae and a decreasing trend of Poaceae, suggesting that alpine steppe was replaced by alpine meadow around 3.5 ka cal BP. This vegetation transformation indicates a generally wetter climate during the middle and late Holocene.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential impacts on vegetation reconstruction accuracy when utilizing a Bayesian age-depth model constructed from 210Pb/137Cs and radiocarbon dating?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a Bayesian age-depth model with 210Pb/137Cs and radiocarbon dating provides a reliable chronology, which improves the accuracy of vegetation reconstruction by offering a precise timeline for sediment layers, allowing for better correlation between pollen samples and historical climate events.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of excluding outlier dates from the age-depth model on the interpretation of past environmental changes in sediment core analysis?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Excluding outlier dates from the age-depth model can lead to a more accurate interpretation of past environmental changes, as it prevents the skewing of chronological data that could result from anomalous dating results, such as those caused by erosion or old carbon input. This ensures that the timeline for environmental events is more reliable.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in extracting pollen grains from sediment samples to ensure accuracy and reliability in pollen concentration calculations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedural steps for extracting pollen grains from sediment samples involve using approximately 1 cm3 of sediment per sample. Coarse particles are removed by sieving through a 200-μm mesh, and one tablet of Lycopodium spores is added to each sample for calculating pollen concentration. Pollen grains are extracted using treatments with 10% HCl, 10% NaOH, and 40% HF, followed by a 7-μm mesh sieving and acetolysis treatment. Pollen grains are then identified and counted under an optical microscope, with modern pollen reference slides and pollen atlases aiding identification.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the age-depth model constructed for sediment cores in paleoclimatic studies to ensure chronological accuracy?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The age-depth model for sediment cores in paleoclimatic studies is constructed using dating results from 210Pb and 137Cs for the top 12 cm of the core, along with radiocarbon dating from 11 samples at different depths. The samples include organic sediment, plant material, and charred material. The model is developed using Bayesian statistics via the Bacon software, ensuring a reliable chronology spanning the last 7,400 years.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are employed to assess sediment composition and environmental changes in lacustrine cores for reconstructing past vegetation and climate conditions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To assess sediment composition and environmental changes, methods employed include grain-size analysis using a MasterSizer 2000 laser grain-size analyser after pretreatment with H2O2, HCl, and sodium hexametaphosphate. Carbonate content is semi-quantitatively analysed using an X'Pert3 X-ray diffractometer, while total organic matter content (TOC) is extracted using an antititration method and quantified with a CE440 Elemental Analyzer after treatment with 10% HCl at 80°C to remove carbonate.

Enablement.Question: How do specific sediment sampling techniques enable the detailed analysis of pollen composition in lacustrine environments?
Enablement.Answer: Detailed analysis of pollen composition is enabled by extracting sediment cores with high temporal resolution. In this domain, a 170-cm-long sediment core was subsampled at 0.5 cm intervals for the upper section and at 1 cm intervals for the rest, resulting in 173 samples. This precise sampling allowed for the extraction and identification of pollen grains using techniques like sieving, adding Lycopodium spores for concentration calculations, and treatments with chemical solutions for pollen extraction.

Expectation.Question: Why might deviations from expected dating results occur when constructing an age-depth model for sediment cores, and how can these deviations be addressed?
Expectation.Answer: Deviations from expected dating results in sediment cores, such as those observed at specific depths, could occur due to factors like erosion or the introduction of old carbon from the catchment area. These deviations can be addressed by identifying and treating them as outliers, which can be excluded from the age-depth model to improve accuracy.

Expectation.Question: What are the reasons for the selection of specific chemical treatments in the pollen extraction process from sediment samples, and how do they contribute to data accuracy?
Expectation.Answer: Specific chemical treatments, such as the use of hydrochloric acid, sodium hydroxide, and hydrofluoric acid, are selected to effectively remove carbonates, organic matter, and silica from sediment samples, respectively. These treatments contribute to data accuracy by ensuring that only pollen grains are isolated and potential contaminants are eliminated, allowing for precise identification and analysis.

Expectation.Question: Why might certain pollen components remain stable over long periods, and what implications does this stability have for interpreting past environmental changes?
Expectation.Answer: Certain pollen components may remain stable over long periods due to consistent ecological conditions or dominant vegetation types that persist despite climate variations. This stability can imply that the regional climate signal has remained relatively unchanged, providing insights into enduring environmental conditions and aiding in the reconstruction of past vegetation and climate dynamics.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential advantages of integrating grain-size and total organic carbon analysis with pollen data in paleoenvironmental studies?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating grain-size and total organic carbon analysis with pollen data in paleoenvironmental studies provides a holistic view of past environmental conditions. While pollen data offer insights into vegetation composition and changes, grain-size analysis helps infer sedimentary processes and hydrodynamic conditions, and total organic carbon provides information on productivity and organic matter accumulation. This multi-proxy approach enhances the understanding of ecosystem dynamics and environmental drivers.

Assertion.Question: I don’t understand how the temporal resolution of pollen records can be achieved over such a long period.
Assertion.Answer: The temporal resolution in this study is achieved by constructing an age-depth model using 210Pb/137Cs and radiocarbon dating on 11 samples, allowing for the establishment of a reliable chronology over the last 7,400 years. This detailed dating process helps maintain a resolution of approximately 40 years per sample.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure how lacustrine sediment cores are used to infer past vegetation and climate changes.
Assertion.Answer: Lacustrine sediment cores provide continuous records of past environmental changes. In this research, pollen analysis, grain-size distribution, total organic carbon, and carbonate content are examined from the sediment core to infer past vegetation types and climate conditions over 7,400 years. Pollen grains serve as indicators of vegetation, while grain-size and organic content provide clues about climatic conditions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the methods used for dating sediment cores and discuss any potential challenges or deviations encountered.
Request/Directive.Answer: The sediment core dating utilized 210Pb and 14C methods, with specific challenges noted, such as deviations at certain depths where dates appeared older than expected. These outliers were likely due to erosion or old carbon input and were excluded from the age-depth model.
